The speaker explains that they have created three fake profiles with different names and backgrounds (Emilie, Vincent, and Mohamed) and are sending them to potential landlords to test their response rates. The speaker reveals that they are the creator of the fake profiles and are analyzing the responses to understand why certain individuals are preferred over others.

The speaker notes that the three profiles have received different numbers of responses, with Emilie receiving the most attention, followed by Vincent, and then Mohamed. The speaker suggests that this may be due to gender or racial biases, but they also acknowledge that there could be other factors at play.

To further analyze the data, the speaker plans to conduct a meta-analysis of 150,000 emails from around the world to identify patterns in response rates based on the level of information provided about the life of the sender. The speaker concludes by emphasizing the importance of understanding these biases and taking steps to combat them.

Transcript:
[On has already dreamed and fantasized, but in reality, we think so much about the subject that we end up living a form of automatism. I see myself in my last dream, so I will comfort you. In this dream, I was a giant agricultural worker and my plant was alive. Suddenly, I felt a gaze upon me. It was the doctor who observed me with those great glasses and his white coat. I decided to move away a bit further on the plant to calm down. And then I saw Bob, another giant. We got along very well. And he told me that we, the biggest ones, had bacteria inside us that were hiding in our cells and lived together with us. He called them symbiotes. Is that it? And he told me that these symbiotes who lived inside us could protect us against diseases or parasites. Even more fascinating, he told me that there were bacteria capable of modifying our behaviors. That's why we were there with Bob in behavioral experiments. We were co-bacteria in scientific studies to help researchers understand how simple bacteria can influence the evolution of species by modifying their behavior. For example, Bob and I had parents who had a big garden. It was like that plant there and not another one. But anyway, there was a problem. Bob and I had the same symbiotes. It's like I'm telling you that you intestinal bacteria can choose to eat either a steak or salad. For Bob, it was obvious. But, doctors, can you tell me how the bacteria that we had with Bob could modify our food choices? It's like I'm saying that you have intestinal bacteria and can choose what you want to eat.
